Hi Peter,

I am glad that you found this paper thought-provoking, while we =
were
writing it my understanding of EC went through some large changes as
w=
ell! You bring up many interesting points.

I agree that one of the most ch=
allenging aspects of applying novelty
search is coming up with an effective=
 behavioral characterization, but
for problems where fitness-based search f=
ails, the effort may be worth
the payoff of a potentially more powerful sea=
rch.

What you say about our choice of behavioral measure in the maze domai=
n
is true, it will conflate two navigators that end on the same point
but u=
se different methods of locomotion to get there. And it is
interesting that=
 you brought that up, because this question of
conflation and choice of beh=
avioral measure has been an area we have
been further investigating. Unless=
 you *completely* characterize
behavior (i.e. the maze navigator's position=
 & angle over all time
steps), there will be some conflation -- the questio=
n is whether for
many domains there is a level of conflation that is accept=
able (or
even beneficial).

Your next point seems to be related, that to co=
mpletely specify
behavior in a very complex domain may be very hard or even=
 infeasible.
This is true. However, it may be sufficient to use a succinct =
summary
of behavior instead of trying to completely specify it (e.g. when
p=
laying a fixed opponent what is the end configuration of the board
for a ch=
eckers player). Once again, by using a summary of behavior
instead of a com=
plete specification, conflation is introduced between
different individuals=
 that have different behaviors, but appear the
same to the behavioral measu=
re.

Behavioral distance is another tricky aspect, and we are looking into
=
ways of doing it in a principled fashion for higher-dimensional
behavioral =
spaces that have multiple types of information (e.g.
integrating heading in=
formation along with Cartesian location of the 
navigator).

Joel

>
> H=
i Joal and Ken,
> 
> This papers and the results presented there really tur=
ned my 
> understandings for EC upside down. This kind of search is really =

> innovative concept that needs to be explored. But I have several 
> ques=
tions about it. 
> 
> It is obvious that you have to define what is a netwo=
rk's behaviour 
> in the task domain and find a way to measure distance bet=
ween two 
> behaviours. I think this is the hardest part of setting up a no=
velty 
> search. For example, in the task domain of maze navigation, you ca=
n 
> simply say that a robot's ending point is its behaviour, but I can 
> =
argue that this is not all, but the way the robot reaches this point 
> can=
 also be considered a behaviour. For example the robot may go from 
> point=
 A to point B straight forward, but it can reach the same point 
> by going=
 forward and spinning. Your model will consider both as the 
> same behavio=
ur while it is obvious the behaviours are different. 
> 
> Another thing is=
 that as the task becomes more complex, it is nearly 
> impossible to defin=
e what a behaviour *is* and how to measure 
> distance between them. Consid=
er the tennis playing robot. Or the 
> checkers playing network. How can yo=
u define the behaviour then? And 
> more, how can you measure *distance* be=
tween behaviours? It's like 
> you have two persons that you know very well=
 and you try to say "the 
> distance between your behaviours is 56.1 units"=
... I don't say it is 
> impossible, it is just too hard. 
> 
> The simples=
t approach is to track the network's output pattern and 
> have this as its=
 behaviour. But then a slight change will mean a 
> different behaviour and=
 the algorithm will end up adding and adding 
> more members to the pool, n=
early every new thing in fact, thus the 
> algorithm will end up as a sligh=
tly optimized version of exhaustive 
> search. 
> 
> But it is really inter=
esting to see novelty search combined with 
> CPPN/HyperNEAT on tasks like =
my biped or just regular NEAT with 
> novelty search on the cool demos I sa=
w in DephiNEAT like the Hopper 
> and the snake. 
> 
> By the way I support=
 the idea that novelty search should sometimes be 
> biased with fitness-ba=
sed search, once a good number of approximate 
> solutions is found. Especi=
ally in domains where the search/behaviour 
> space is vast. 
> 
> I believ=
e that the search space that NEAT searches directly (the 
> genotype space)=
 is much more big than the behaviour space, simply 
> because many many dif=
ferent structures/weight configurations can 
> represent the same exact beh=
aviour. The task domain can restrict the 
> possible behaviours further, bu=
t not in all task domains. But even if 
> there are infinite possible behav=
iours in a space, novelty search is 
> still better than random search beca=
use it searches explicitly for 
> new behaviours, so new genomes that do th=
e same thing will not be 
> rewarded. 
> 
> Peter

 This

es

ause

>=
 > fitness-based search.

ote from the end of our

andon them."
